 I assume by "fungus thing" you actually mean Candidiasis, also known as Thrush or a yeast infection. A fungal infection most commonly caused by a diploid fungus known as Candida albicans. Candidiasis is a far less common symptom of HIV infection. By itself in the absense of other symptoms, it would rarely ever lead to an HIV test. Candidiasis is much more prevelent in females than males, however it does occur in males. I still however find it unlikely that a physician would test someone for HIV simply on the diagnosis of Candidiasis. It just does not happen like that. 
 
 But now we get to the true miracle of your account. 30 years later, and still HIV free. This is where the true miracle comes in. The virus that causes AIDS was first identified in 1983 (that would be 24 years ago if my 3rd grade math calculations are correct.) It was initially named lymphadenopathy-associated virus (LAV) by the French scientists who discovered it, then in 1984 renamed human T lymphotropic virus type III (HTLV-III) by Gallo et.al. The term HIV was not coined until the French and US came together to agree on 1 term for the virus, finally settling on human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in the year 1986. 
 
 Now, the first test for HIV was the ELISA (Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay). It is highly sensitive, and very nonspecific, which means it gives a positive result easily even when there is no HIV present. As many as four out of five ELISA tests cannot be confirmed by Western Blot. This test was first developed and used in 1985 (which if my 3rd grade math is still warmed up, would make make identification of HIV (HTLV-III) possible only 22 years ago). Sure...22...it's like 30 sorta.
 
 Yes indeed, truely a miracle to behold!!!

 I assume by "fungus thing" you actually mean Candidiasis, also known as Thrush or a yeast infection. A fungal infection most commonly caused by a diploid fungus known as Candida albicans. Candidiasis is a far less common symptom of HIV infection. By itself in the absense of other symptoms, it would rarely ever lead to an HIV test. Candidiasis is much more prevelent in females than males, however it does occur in males. I still however find it unlikely that a physician would test someone for HIV simply on the diagnosis of Candidiasis. It just does not happen like that. 
 
 But now we get to the true miracle of your account. 30 years later, and still HIV free. This is where the true miracle comes in. The virus that causes AIDS was first identified in 1983 (that would be 24 years ago if my 3rd grade math calculations are correct.) It was initially named lymphadenopathy-associated virus (LAV) by the French scientists who discovered it, then in 1984 renamed human T lymphotropic virus type III (HTLV-III) by Gallo et.al. The term HIV was not coined until the French and US came together to agree on 1 term for the virus, finally settling on human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in the year 1986. 
 
 Now, the first test for HIV was the ELISA (Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay). It is highly sensitive, and very nonspecific, which means it gives a positive result easily even when there is no HIV present. As many as four out of five ELISA tests cannot be confirmed by Western Blot. This test was first developed and used in 1985 (which if my 3rd grade math is still warmed up, would make make identification of HIV (HTLV-III) possible only 22 years ago).  The problem with the HIV example is that it's something that is physically possible without supernatural intervention. HIV is a notoriously variable virion: at the extreme 'weak' end of its virulence bell curve it's perfectly feasible that some variants simply can't persist in patients. The problem with labelling a virus as '100% incurable' is the same as with labelling all swans as white: it takes only one counter-observation to refute it. No-one would call a black swan a miracle; nor need we regard the postulated full recovery from HIV as such.
 
 In a nut-shell, it has to be a personally witnessed or incontrovertibly documented event which is genuinely inexplicable in any other way. Otherwise, Hume has said all that needs saying.
